medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient was diagnosed at age 5 years, with the adenoma being invasive and causing compression of the optic chiasm. Initial treatment involved bromocriptine, but the tumor increased in size, leading to transsphenoidal surgery in 2000. Due to extensive invasion of the left cavernous sinus, complete excision was not possible. Postoperative management included octreotide and cabergoline, and in 2001, fractionated radiotherapy was performed. The patient subsequently developed GH deficiency.
medical_history.past_medical_history: The patient has a heterozygous germline mutation in the MEN1 gene (c.525C/H11022G; p.H139D). Previous treatments included transsphenoidal surgery, GH replacement therapy, and thyroid hormone replacement therapy.
medical_history.family_history: A family history of MEN1 is apparent, with the father and two aunts having hyperparathyroidism; one of the aunts also has prolactinoma. All affected relatives harbor the same H139D mutation.
